thread.title: Trump Today: Making waves internationally -
thread.title_full: Trump Today: Making waves internationally - The Boston Globe

title: Trump Today: Making waves internationally -
text:
Google+
By Martin Finucane Globe Staff February 02, 2017
Welcome to Trump Today, a one-stop entry point for the latest news on the 45th president of the United States.
Afternoon update
Advertisement
President Donald J. Trump said at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington he would work to “totally destroy’’ a provision that bars churches and other tax-exempt organizations from supporting political candidates.
The White House said Trump’s warning in a phone call to the president of Mexico about sending US troops to deal with “bad hombres down there” was lighthearted. But Trump himself said in his prayer breakfast speech his “tough phone calls with world leaders” were necessary.
Get Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here At the breakfast, Trump’s showbiz background showed as he asked for prayers for better TV ratings for Arnold Schwarzenegger. Schwarzenegger quickly fired off a witty comeback.
View Story Trump’s call with Australia should’ve been a breeze. It wasn’t. President Trump blasted Prime Minister Turnbull over a refugee agreement in a phone call over the weekend.
Trump tells Mexico to take care of ‘bad hombres’
Trump and Iran traded statements, with Trump stepping up warnings over Tehran’s missile tests and an Iranian official saying it was not the first time an ‘‘inexperienced person” had threatened his country.
For many US veterans, Trump’s travel ban makes sense, the Globe’s Brian MacQuarrie reports.
Advertisement
Massachusetts US Representative Richard Neal, the top Democrat on House Ways and Means, attended a White House meeting with Trump Thursday. With major tax changes on the GOP agenda, he may need to be a miracle-worker. The Globe’s Victoria McGrane looks at what he’s facing.
Politically, Trump is good for Elizabeth Warren, the Globe’s James Pindell reports in his Ground Game analysis.
More Trump on the world stage
Secretary of State Rex Tillerson sought to reassure US diplomats anxious after two weeks of a Trump presidency. He also warned that change was coming.
In what should have been a friendly phone call, Trump blasted the Australian prime minister over a refugee agreement and boasted about the magnitude of his electoral college win. Twenty-five minutes in, he abruptly ended it, according to senior U.S. officials. White House spokesman Sean Spicer said Trump was “unbelievably disappointed” with the refugee agreement.
The US military said it was investigating last weekend’s anti-terror raid in Yemen and that innocent civilians, including children, were apparently killed.
The Trump administration on Wednesday kept a low-key approach to the outbreak of violence in Ukraine, where the government accuses Russian-backed forces of escalating attacks.
What’s he been tweeting?
He tweeted about his problem with Australia at 10:55 p.m. Wednesday.
Do you believe it? The Obama Administration agreed to take thousands of illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 2, 2017
In a tweet at 6:13 a.m. Thursday, he also made a veiled threat to cut funds to the University of California at Berkeley, where a talk by Milo Yiannopoulos, a polarizing Breitbart News editor, was canceleded after protesters threw smoke bombs, broke windows and started a bonfire.
If U.C. Berkeley does not allow free speech and practices violence on innocent people with a different point of view - NO FEDERAL FUNDS?
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 2, 2017
He also posted tweets Wednesday night and Thursday morning criticizing Iran and the Iran nuclear deal. And he said it was “a great honor” to attend, along with his daughter Ivanka, the return of the remains of an American serviceman killed in an anti-terror raid in Yemen. “To a great and brave man - thank you!” he tweeted.
The headlines in Boston
At Harvard Law, Trump’s Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch stood out in a campus full of liberals. (including former president Obama), the Globe’s Michael Levenson reports.
Harvard Law Yearbook 1990
Gorsuch at Harvard Law
Despite orders by federal judges in Boston and elsewhere halting Trump’s travel ban, hundreds of US-bound visa holders were denied boarding, a previously undisclosed State Department reveals, the Globe’s Maria Sacchetti reports.
A Boston-bound Iranian scientist with a visa sued over the travel ban.
GE contracts could reportedly be threatened by travel ban.
More headlines
Trump digressed from an African-American History Month listening session Wednesday to bash the media and caught social media backlash for remarks about African-American icon Frederick Douglass.
Trump’s nomination of school choice advocate Betsy DeVos as education secretary appeared in jeopardy with two Republican senators saying they would vote against her.
